name: Methaqualone (Quaalude)
summary: A sedative-hypnotic formerly used for insomnia and anxiety, withdrawn due to high abuse potential.
description: Methaqualone is a quinazolinone-class sedative-hypnotic drug that was introduced in the 1960s as a treatment for insomnia and anxiety. It became widely misused as a recreational drug in the 1970s under the brand name Quaalude, known for producing euphoria, relaxation, and disinhibition. Due to its high potential for abuse, dependence, and overdose, it was withdrawn from the market in most countries by the mid-1980s and classified as a Schedule I controlled substance in the United States.

contraindications: Current classification as Schedule I controlled substance
monitoring_required: Signs of misuse or dependence (historical context)

sections.text: Enhances the effects of GABA at the GABA-A receptor complex, producing sedation, muscle relaxation, and hypnosis.

adult.historical: Typical hypnotic dose was 150–300 mg at bedtime

sections.geriatric: Not recommended due to increased risk of adverse effects

sections.text: Onset within 30 minutes; duration 4–8 hours (historical data).

sections.black_box: High potential for abuse, dependence, and fatal overdose; withdrawn from medical use in most countries.
other: Dangerous interactions with alcohol and other CNS depressants
Severe withdrawal symptoms after chronic use

items: Respiratory and cardiovascular status in overdose cases

sections.geriatrics: Avoid due to increased sensitivity to CNS depressants

sections.text: Historical use required gradual dose reduction to prevent withdrawal symptoms including anxiety, insomnia, and seizures.
